body: @jmelchio

I realized that the parameters can have three states ( false, true and empty ) and I was trying to use a boolean to store that state. I fixed that, and I have simplified the use cases:

* `list gateways --senders-only` and `list gateways --senders=true` will show only senders.
* `list gateways --receivers-only` and `list gateways --receivers-only=true` will show only receivers.
* Any attempt to use `--senders-only` and `--receivers-only` together will return error, no matter the value introduced.

I like this solution instead of the previous one, I think its easier to understand how the parameters can be used.
I just updated solution with, possibility to update InetSocketAddress in LocatorAddress. Or I can modify it with your proposal

@mivanac Something like this attached change should really be the only thing necessary. 

[LocatorAddress.java.zip](https://github.com/apache/geode/files/4073085/LocatorAddress.java.zip)
@mivanac While the period had expired not all comment had been addressed. There are still unresolved comments in the wiki regarding this proposal.

Is there a possibility in which we fail the lucene query when it is executed in mixed version servers, like by throwing a particular exception that does not trigger re-execution. I am also working on your branch with this commit and trying to figure out if we can stop the query execution with a failure.
Warning! My suggestion is untested. Just a POC.
We wanted to implement this SSL extension, similar to SecurityManager implementation. And we are expecting just one implementation to be executed.
Thanks for comments and proposal.
@jmelchio for your review.

@mkevo Do I understand correctly that setting the filename to the empty string `""` will now disable writing stats to a file? Formatting of the JIRA description may have deleted quote marks, so just double-checking.
@davebarnes97 if approved, perhaps the Apache Geode website should also have a link to this new artifact starting with 1.12.0

> Maybe it would be better to just not build the zip file the first place? You can do something like this in gradle/release.gradle in the `geode-examples` project.
> 
> ```
> tasks.distZip.enabled = false
> ```

fixed in https://github.com/apache/geode-examples/pull/91
With last update of  LocatorAddress, some methods become unnecessary, so I removed them. Also test with IP change are no more valid.

> @mkevo Do I understand correctly that setting the filename to the empty string `""` will now disable writing stats to a file? Formatting of the JIRA description may have deleted quote marks, so just double-checking.

To disable writing stats to file you can use this two options:

alter runtime --statistic-archive-file=
alter runtime --statistic-archive-file=""

As _alter runtime_ command go through all parameters and check it, in case we don't specified any parameters some commands like `alter runtime --member=server` will be successful. So I made a change to accept only file names that has _.gfs_ suffix. To disable it just provide some random string without _.gfs_.

@mkevo If the change you describe is a response to my comment on the JIRA ticket, thanks. To keep all discussion in a single location, I'll summarize my comment here:
  I am uncomfortable with the syntax `alter runtime --statistic-archive-file=` where no value follows 
  the equals sign. I would like to see comments from the Apache Geode developers' mailing list on this 
  proposal.
However, I am also uncomfortable with this latest change. If I understand it correctly, to enable this property, the value following the equals sign must be a filename with one of two suffixes: '.gfs' or '.gz'. Any other string disables the archive-to-a-file function.
I find this counterintuitive. In my opinion:
The simplest way to add a turn-off function to this existing property would be to specify an empty string, using a syntax you suggested earlier: `alter runtime --statistic-archive-file=""`.
If that isn't workable, then (again, my opinion) the next best approach would be to add a boolean option that sets statistics archiving to 'true' or 'false'. 
Again, I would like to see this put to the dev list for additional thoughts.

> Why use the strongly typed InternalDistributedMember rather than it's string representation?

I don't see which part of the code is your comment about, but I suppose is referred to `ServerLocationAndMemberId` class, am I right? I used the string representation because its the minimum information I think I need. Thanks for the fast review!

> > Why use the strongly typed InternalDistributedMember rather than it's string representation?
> 
> I don't see which part of the code is your comment about, but I suppose is referred to `ServerLocationAndMemberId` class, am I right? I used the string representation because its the minimum information I think I need. Thanks for the fast review!

Sorry, I should have attached it to a line of code. Yes, the issues is with using the `String` since it we have a more strongly typed value the string is derived from why not use it. 

If you consider my other comment about the ID really being the only unique part of the key anyway it makes a stronger argument for the strong type over the string as the key for the maps.

> I'm not 100% sure I understand what this is implementing. Clearing a BucketRegion still fails the same way it has in the past.
> 
> I wrote a function that attempts to clear a PartitionedRegion by clearing all of its primary BucketRegions. To do that, it tried these API:
> 
> ```
> br.basicClear(regionEvent);
> br.basicClear(regionEvent, true);
> br.cmnClearRegion(regionEvent, true, true);
> ```
> 
> No matter which of those it called, this exception occurs:
> 
> ```
> Caused by: org.apache.geode.InternalGemFireError: Trying to clear a bucket region that was not destroyed or in initialization.
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.updateSizeOnClearRegion(BucketRegion.java:2128)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.AbstractRegionMap.clear(AbstractRegionMap.java:460)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.clearEntries(BucketRegion.java:2479)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.LocalRegion.clearRegionLocally(LocalRegion.java:8544)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.cmnClearRegion(BucketRegion.java:578)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BasicClearBucketRegionFunction.basicClear(BasicClearBucketRegionFunction.java:32)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BasicClearBucketRegionFunction.execute(BasicClearBucketRegionFunction.java:21)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.execute.AbstractExecution.executeFunctionLocally(AbstractExecution.java:328)
> 	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.execute.AbstractExecution.lambda$executeFunctionOnLocalPRNode$0(AbstractExecution.java:273)
> 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
> 	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
> 	at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.ClusterOperationExecutors.runUntilShutdown(ClusterOperationExecutors.java:449)
> 	at org.apache.geode.distributed.internal.ClusterOperationExecutors.doFunctionExecutionThread(ClusterOperationExecutors.java:379)
> 	at org.apache.geode.logging.internal.executors.LoggingThreadFactory.lambda$newThread$0(LoggingThreadFactory.java:119)
> 	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
> ```
> 
> AFAICT, a BucketRegion still can't be cleared.
> 
> When I hack-implemented this feature, I changed BucketRegion.updateSizeOnClearRegion to do this instead of throwing the InternalGemFireError. I'm not sure if this is valid, though.
> 
> ```
> oldMemValue = this.bytesInMemory.getAndSet(0);
> ```

This looks like a loose-end I did not found earlier. I will do that fix. And I will add this dunit test case in PR.clear.

@PurelyApplied I have walked through the expected-pom.xml changes and looked at what all has moved from `compile` to `runtime` and nothing jumped out as a "But Robert, we use that symbol in a public API" kind of problem. The JIRA does call this out as a potential problem for downstream customers.

Just tested against `geode-examples` and saw that `commons-lang3` is no longer being emitted by us, and was expected by the example. Going back to inspect the packages to see if `geode` emits any symbols owned by `commons`
@jmelchio

Hi,

can you share some info regarding this internal tests, so we can speed up detection of problem in this PR?

Thanks

> Hi,
> 
> can you share some info regarding this internal tests, so we can speed up detection of problem in this PR?
> 
> Thanks

Hi Mario,

The purpose of the internal test is to force async message queueing and confirm that no deadlocks occur. The test in question starts 6 servers with 5 regions in the cluster, each using a custom CacheListener that sleeps the thread for 2 ms when onCreate() is called with a particular event key in order to encourage queueing. Random events are delivered to the regions, including ones using the key that will trigger a 2ms sleep.

Each server is configured to run with 5 threads, conserve sockets is set to true, async distribution timeout is 5ms, async queue timeout is 60000ms and async max queue size is 10.

We consistently see the test hang when two members log that they are sleeping due to the onCreate() listener call. If only one member has logged that call then the test continues regardless of how many times its called, but as soon as a second member logs it, the test encounters problems and a hang is declared 5 minutes later.

We will continue to investigate this issue after the weekend, but I hope that the information here is helpful to you in the meantime.

Hi Donal,

thanx for info.
But if you have any failing tests, that are reason for revert, could you push them to community.
With current approach, it is hard to troubleshoot, and this way all will be transparent.

Regards.

@rhoughton-pivot I pulled this branch and built it in IntelliJ and ran some JUnit tests in IntelliJ and didn't see any hiccups ✓

making some comments inline…

> Hi Donal,
> 
> thanx for info.
> But if you have any failing tests, that are reason for revert, could you push them to community.
> With current approach, it is hard to troubleshoot, and this way all will be transparent.
> 
> Regards.

Hi Mario,

Regrettably, I'm not able to share the actual test that caught this problem due to licensing issues; it's a proprietary test used as part of ensuring the product I work on is enterprise-ready. We've been trying to reproduce the issue in a DUnit test that can be shared with the community but haven't been able to do so yet, as the exact circumstances needed to cause it to show up are proving elusive.

I will be certain to let you know as soon as I have a way of reproducing the issue locally and will push any tests to a branch on my fork to allow debugging, as well as creating a Jira ticket with all the details.
